data.text: Contents
Introduction

The wound healing process is a complex sequence of events and whilst many wounds heal without any complications some, such as cavity wounds, can present challenges for clinicians. This can be in terms of accurate wound assessment, and appropriate treatment regimes.

It is essential that all patients presenting with a cavity wound receive a holistic assessment, and have a structured and well documented wound management care plan in place with clear and concise instructions including wound review and wound evaluation dates. This will ensure patients receive appropriate wound management, and reduce the likelihood of further wound complications. This in turn will facilitate the best potential healing outcomes for the patient wherever possible.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
To set minimum safety standards for Registered Nurses and Midwives, and Medical personnel who may be required to manage a cavity wound.
To describe minimum standard for patient records
To ensure local governance requirements are met
Definitions

table_items.text: A clear definitive and standardised definition of a cavity wound does not exist. The literature1 provides different definitions of what constitutes a cavity wound including, amongst these, any wound that extends into the dermis and exposes underlying structures for example tendon, muscle and bone2. A cavity can exist in most wound types, and can result from, for example, surgical intervention, and subsequent wound dehiscence, traumatic wounds, chronic wounds such as pressure ulcers, diabetic foot, leg ulcers, or malignant wounds. A cavity wound may present with additional features of undermining, sinus or fistula formation, bridging.

Standards of practice
This SOP does not cover management of non-cavity wounds regardless of cause of aetiology. Such situations will be covered by the Wound Care policy.
Information relating to the patient and their presenting problem is collated in accordance with standards set by the practitioner's professional organisation.
Information relating to treatment options is identified based on the best available evidence in accordance with standards set by the practitioner's professional organisation.
Patients will be individually assessed by an appropriately registered practitioner to ensure it is appropriate to apply dressings to the cavity wound.
Referral to the Tissue Viability Team should be made if any wound related concerns are identified, or if the wound is not responding to evidence-based standard of care.
Process

The aim of packing a cavity wound is to allow drainage and absorption of exudate, to prevent the base of the wound from becoming too wet or harbouring bacteria and to prevent the skin healing over the cavity before it has closed. Packing the cavity very tightly is poor practice; this will cause pain, inhibit free draining of exudate, and potentially cause damage to the newly granulating tissue (Tickle 2021).
A thorough wound assessment is essential to determine the nature of the wound bed in order to aid appropriate treatment.
Necrotic or sloughy tissue may be present at the wound bed, however this may be challenging to fully visualise, access and remove.

The challenges of effective exudate management, and prevention and management of wound infection must be considered and addressed through holistic assessment, and the development of a robust wound management plan.
Delayed healing, and the increased risks associated with this, may arise from managing a cavity wound ineffectively.
Wound management
Treatment is undertaken in a clean and private environment with adequate washing facilities nearby.
A gown, towel or other cover is provided to maintain the patient's privacy and dignity.
The practitioner washes their hands before and after the procedure.
The practitioner uses a sterile wound dressing technique.
Pre-assessment
To carry out this procedure you will need the following:

table_items.text: Sterile dressing pack and sterile plastic probe or wound swab
Flat dressing, or ribbon dressing depending on cavity type. Topical Negative Pressure (TNP) pack (either kerlix gauze or granufoam filler, and if required low adherent wound contact layer).
Trust approved skin barrier product; this may be required depending on the outcome of a thorough wound assessment

Sachet normal saline or chlorhexidine solution for wound irrigation / cleansing. If either covert or overt signs of wound infection are present consider use of a Trust approved surfactant as the cleansing agent
Appropriate secondary dressing and fixation as required

data.text: Wound assessment

table_items.text: Examine the cavity bed; use a torch if required. Measure and document the maximum length, width and depth of the cavity wound in centimetres (cm). Document position of patient when examining the cavity to ensure consistent approach to subsequent assessment and review. Probe the wound gently, but thoroughly and with caution (especially if the full depth is not visible), with either a sterile plastic probe, or wound swab, using the clock face method.
In order to obtain and document baseline data. This will enable clinicians to assess wound progress in line with endpoint / goal set for the patient

Larger cavities may require a sterile gloved finger to probe the inside of the cavity. This is useful if there is concern about bone involvement which can lead to osteomyelitis. Assess the cavity and surrounding skin for clinical signs of wound infection. Examine the amount and type of exudate. Clear moderate amounts of exudate indicate normal wound healing. Malodourous, purulent, thick, copious amounts of exudate, or bleeding is likely to indicate wound infection. Document anatomical site of the cavity, and tissue type present, if this can be visualised Request wound photography on initial assessment and on change of presentation, if appropriate to do so, or as soon as clinically appropriate to do so.

data.text: Wound management

table_items.text: At each dressing change always count, and document, in the patient's clinical record, and wound management care plan, the number of dressings that are removed and reinserted in the cavity wound (i.e. number of flat or ribbon dressings, TNP filler (gauze or granufoam, and if used non-adherent contact layer). Clearly document the name of the dressing products used in the wound management / pressure ulcer care plan. If on removal of the dressing products there is a discrepancy in the number of dressings applied versus removed, the Nurse should contact the patient's Medical / Surgical Team for urgent advice. This situation, and action taken, should be clearly documented in the patient's clinical record. Select appropriate packing type: A) a flat dressing may be appropriate for a shallow cavity wound or one with undermining, or with a wide aperture. The dressing may need to be folded into the cavity and / or undermining. B) a ribbon dressing will be required for a cavity
To ensure safe and appropriate practice by an appropriately registered clinician

wound with a narrow aperture or with a sinus formation Cleanse the wound. Note: A sinus wound needs to be flushed with saline to ensure any exudate at the wound base is removed. The remainder of the fluid can then be removed using a wick of gauze before applying the packing. Leave a 2cm tab of ribbon dressing at the wound margin. Do not insert one ribbon dressing on top of another, or tie dressings together to increase the overall length. If more than one ribbon dressing is required, each dressing must be left with a 2cm tab at the wound margin. Do not pack tightly or firmly; the dressing will swell as it absorbs exudate. If the cavity is packed too tightly this may impede free drainage of exudate and may also delay granulation Apply an appropriate secondary dressing depending on anatomical location – for example wound pad and bandage, or foam bordered adhesive Dressing change frequency will depend on factors such as exudate levels, wound infection, condition of the surrounding skinUse of a Trust approved skin barrier product⃰ may be required to protect the peri-wound; this will depend on the outcome of a thorough wound assessment.Reassess the cavity wound at each dressing change and document the outcome in the patient's wound management / pressure ulcer care plan. Update the wound care plan at least weekly, or more frequently if there is a change of wound condition If there are signs of deterioration or wound infection report to the patient's Medical / Surgical Team and refer to the Tissue Viability Service for their support and input.

data.text: Training requirements

No specific training requirements. However this procedure should only be undertaken by an appropriately registered clinician. If a student nurse is required to undertake this procedure as part of their training, their practice should be supervised by an appropriately registered clinician.

Appendix 1: Types of cavity wounds
The Table below is a useful tool to illustrate different types of cavity wounds

table_items.text: The upper layer indicates the epidermis and dermis, the second pale layer is subcutaneous tissue, and the deeper layer is fascia, muscle and bone.
Simple cavity wound: a cavity of this type may go down to the muscle, bone or fascia, but you can see that all edges are clear, with no tracking or undermining present.

Cavity wound with undermining: type of cavity will need careful assessment and measurement using a plastic probe and the clock face method used to determine the depth of the undermining, just below the dermis and into the subcutaneous tissue.
Cavity wound with a sinus: which can hold and trap exudate, making the base of the wound very wet thus macerating it further, causing the sinus cavity to increase in size.
Fistula: A fistula is an abnormal communication between two hollow organs or between a hollow organ and the exterior.

Gently place the ribbon dressing into the centre of the wound bed, with a 2cm tab hanging outside of the top of the wound, a little like a candle wick, so that the exudate can be absorbed up and out of the wound. The dressing can be laid gently to the side of the wound so that it is easy to remove. Cover with an appropriate absorbent adhesive dressing. If peri-wound area is at vulnerable, use a barrier film to help protect. DO NOT PACK TIGHTLY OR EVEN FIRMLY
